I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The project will support the Government of Uzbekistan to expand access to improved 
water supply and sanitation (WSS) services for 2.9 million people in all seven cities and 15 districts 
of  Tashkent  Province.  It  will  improve  WSS  service  delivery  and  operational  efficiency  by 
(i) rehabilitating and expanding wastewater systems in seven cities; (ii) enhancing decentralized 
wastewater disposal systems in rural areas; (iii) increasing bulk and consumption water metering; 
and (iv) strengthening the institutional capacity of Tashkent Suvtaminot (TST), the provincial water 
supply and wastewater utility. The project will complement and draw on experience from two 
ongoing water supply projects funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in Tashkent 
Province.1  
 
2.  The total project cost is estimated at $185.8 million. ADB will finance $161.0 million using 
its ordinary capital resources, and the government will contribute $24.8 million in the form of taxes 
and duties. The project supports ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2019–2023 for Uzbekistan, 
which aims to develop municipal infrastructure and services, linked to regulatory and institutional 
reform, to ensure long-term sustainability.2 This technical assistance (TA) is not listed in the 
business plan. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  Tashkent Province, in the northeast of Uzbekistan, was established in 1938 and spans 
more than 15,600 square kilometers of land with a population of about 2.95 million—1.45 million 
urban (49%) and 1.50 million rural (51%). Accounting for almost 30% of the nation’s gross 
domestic product, the province is recognized as one of the largest and most developed industrial 
regions in the nation. Tashkent Province has 6 major cities that are seen as key economic drivers, 
15 districts, 97 semi-urbanized rural settlements, and 885 rural villages. Three major rivers are 
regarded as vital for water supply, irrigation, and recreational water use in the province. 
 
4.  Tashkent Province suffers from persistent urban service limitations and lack of access to 
quality WSS services. Of the province’s 2.95 million population, only 1.60 million (54%) have 
access to water supply while only 0.50 million (17%) are connected to municipal wastewater 
systems. The province’s Soviet-era WSS infrastructure is decrepit, has exhausted its useful life, 
and is in need of immediate rehabilitation and renewal. 
 
5.  Ongoing  ADB-financed  projects  in  Tashkent  Province  cover  six  cities  (Akhangaran, 
Almalyk, Angren, Bekabod, Chirchik, and Yangiyul); one urban center in Chinaz district; and 
three districts (Chinaz, Yangiyul, and Zangiota) serving a population of 1.2 million. 
 
6.  TST, a state-owned utility company, is responsible for the management of WSS services 
in Tashkent Province. TST’s institutional weaknesses include insufficient institutional structure; 
dysfunctional  and  fragmented  regulatory  and  institutional  frameworks;  poor  interagency 
coordination; limited sector planning; unclear regulatory compliance and ineffective enforcement; 
and  lack  of  capacity  in  corporate  development,  finance  and  accounting,  human  resources

7.  Strategy 20303 acknowledges that the promotion of effective, timely delivery of public 
services to support through strengthened institutional capacity and improved quality of public 
service delivery will help developing member countries improve governance and create an 
enabling  environment  for  sustainable  growth.  Better  management  and  maintenance  of 
infrastructure assets and improved business operations, with greater use of information and 
communication technology and the adoption of international best practices, are essential—setting 
the course for ADB to help strengthen the capacity of developing member countries to improve 
public service delivery. 
 
8.  The TA consultants will support TST to implement institutional reforms and capacity 
building efforts following the institutional development road map developed for TST. The overall 
purpose of the TA is to ensure the achievement of institutional development goals and milestones 
set forth in TST’s institutional development road map. 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: TST’s institutional capacity strengthened and 
its operational efficiency and effectiveness improved. The TA will have the following outcome: the 
improvement of TST’s capacity in the areas of (i) institutional structure and business process, 
(ii) human resources management, (iii) financial and operational sustainability, and (iv) private 
sector participation and public–private partnership contracting.4 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
10.  The expected outputs are:  
 
11.  Output  1:  Annual institutional  development  assessment reports  prepared.  The 
reports include (i) the progress and results of TST’s institutional development, reflecting key 
indicators as indicated in the road map; and (ii) evaluation of results and recommendations for 
improvement. 
  
12.  Output 2: Technical presentations and workshops on the subjects of WSS services 
conducted. This output comprises a series of technical presentation and training workshops on 
improvement of operational efficiency and service performance. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $800,000, of which (i) $400,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by Spanish Cooperation Fund for Technical Assistance; and (ii) $400,000 will be financed 
by Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund, both to be administered by ADB. 
The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
14.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff and some 
office spaces for project meeting purposes. The government was informed that approval of the 
TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TA. The Urban Development and Water Division of ADB’s Central 
and West Asia Department will implement the TA and be accountable for the TA outputs. It will 
carry out administration and supervision, implementation oversight, and communication with 
consultants and stakeholders.  
 
16.  The TA will be implemented from December 2021 to December 2027. The TA does not 
require any logistical support from the UJSC and TST.

18.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consulting firm following the quality- and cost-
based selection method, with a quality–cost ratio of 90:10, using full, simplified, or bio-data 
technical proposal. Individual consultants will be selected using the individual consultant selection 
method to provide specialized technical and administrative inputs to fulfill ADB due diligence 
requirements and enhance project readiness. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB 
Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  its  associated  project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions.5 Lump-sum or output-based contracts will be 
considered for consulting services to reduce the administrative burden and improve the economy, 
efficiency, and value for money. The consultants will procure goods and equipment purchased 
under the TA, including laptop and desktop computers, licensed software for laptop and desktop 
computers, large high-definition computer screens, scanners, printers, digital storage hard drives, 
and accessories. These will be turned over to the executing agency at or before the completion 
of the TA.
